head.title: In Rite of Spring, Couples Makes Cut at Augusta for 23rd Straight Time

hedline.hl1: In Rite of Spring, Couples Makes Cut at Augusta for 23rd Straight Time

block.p: In a season of limited golf swings and loads of back pain, Fred Couples arrived this week at Augusta National Golf Club seeking a few good golf shots and the continuation of a Masters streak.
By sundown Friday, he had achieved both. Couples, the 1992 champion, shot a four-over-par 76 to make his 23rd consecutive cut at the Masters, tying the record held by Gary Player.
In a season of limited golf swings and loads of back pain, Fred Couples arrived this week at Augusta National Golf Club seeking a few good golf shots and the continuation of a Masters streak.
By sundown Friday, he had achieved both. Couples, the 1992 champion, shot a four-over-par 76 to make his 23rd consecutive cut at the Masters, tying the record held by Gary Player.

His round completed, Couples signed his scorecard and walked up a hill behind the 18th green. With a 10-shot deficit behind the leaders, Brett Wetterich and Tim Clark, his chances of winning a second green jacket seemed nonexistent. Still, he found comfort in the familiar: golf at Augusta National on the weekend.
''To make the cut is great,'' he said.

Couples, 47, has been so worn down by pain this year that he entered the Masters having played only two competitive rounds this season. A year ago at the Masters, he played in the final group with Phil Mickelson before finishing tied for third. That would be a long shot this year.
''The way I played, I was a little sloppy,'' Couples said. ''I could have been better. It's a hard course. It's not a back issue.''

Nevertheless, Couples has had his back seize up at unexpected times in his life. He said he was not sure when he would play again after the Masters. The on-again, off-again nature of his pain has bogged him down.
''This is probably the only tournament I'll play in,'' he said. ''It's driving me crazy.''

AN UNKIND CUT -- The dash to make the cut, which fell at eight-over-par 152, was an eventful exercise Friday. The 57-year-old Tom Watson seemed a cinch to make it to the weekend until he made a triple bogey on the 18th hole. He missed the cut by a stroke.
''Not a good way to end the Masters,'' he said. ''It was very disappointing. These greens are the toughest I've seen them.''
The 71-year-old Gary Player, in his 50th Masters tournament, finished at 16-over-par 160.

A HOME FOR TIGER'S EVENT -- Not all the news Tiger Woods has received at the Masters has been bad. Late Thursday evening, his inaugural tournament, the AT&T National, secured Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md., as its home through 2008.
This year's event will be played from July 2-8. It is a limited-field tournament of 120 players that will benefit the Tiger Woods Foundation.

COOL TIMES IN GEORGIA -- Unseasonably cool temperatures were expected to continue through the weekend at Augusta National. The forecast for Saturday is for sunny skies and a high of 57 degrees. Sunday's forecast calls for sunny skies and a high of 62 degrees. On each day, a frost warning is possible, which could delay the start of play.
DO NOT CALL -- Brett Wetterich has the kind of friends who call at 1:30 in the morning even when their buddy has an important tee time in just a few hours.
Wetterich, tied for the lead at the Masters, has plenty to worry about without those kind of distractions.

Wetterich got his share of the lead by shooting a one-over-par 73 Friday, and he did it even though he may have been a bit tired for his 8:55 a.m. start. You see, his phone rang a little late the night before.
''I'm the type of person that gets phone calls like that every now and then,'' he said. ''My buddies forget that I'm playing the Masters and I have to get up at 5:30.'' (AP)
TOO LATE FOR CLARKE -- Darren Clarke pulled his game together a little too late.

Even with bogeys on the last two holes, Clarke shot a one-under-par 71 yesterday -- a 12-stroke turnaround from the first round. But his 83 on Thursday put him 10 over for the tournament, two strokes above the cut line.
It's only the third time he has missed the cut in 10 trips to Augusta.
''Strangely enough, I didn't play that badly yesterday,'' he said. ''Today I played just a little bit better. I had a lot of chances. Almost gave me a chance to make the cut there.''
Clarke made only one birdie and seven pars on Thursday to go with eight bogeys and two double bogeys. He made three birdies yesterday but was bogey-free until his last two holes.
At least Clarke had a nice fallback plan.
''I'm back to the beach in the Bahamas,'' Clarke said with a grin. ''Bye-bye.'' (AP)
GOLF
